benchmark_details.name: From Capabilities to Performance: Evaluating Key Functional Properties of LLM Architectures in Penetration Testing
benchmark_details.overview: This study presents a comprehensive evaluation of multiple LLM-based agents in realistic penetration testing scenarios, analyzing their empirical performance and recurring failure patterns through targeted augmentations.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate the functional properties and performance of LLM-based agents in penetration testing tasks and identify improvements through targeted augmentations.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The focus on penetration testing tasks and specific LLM configurations tested may not fully represent complex enterprise networks.

data.source: Hack The Box and Metasploitable platforms used for realistic penetration testing scenarios.
data.annotation: Empirical performance was recorded through model response evaluations in structured penetration testing tasks.

methodology.calculation: Success is based on task completion rates, command generation quality, and human intervention.
methodology.interpretation: A high SCR indicates successful task completion, while a low FR indicates fewer failed attempts.
methodology.baseline_results: Various LLMs showed varying completion rates, e.g., GPT-4 achieved 72.7% on reconnaissance tasks.
methodology.validation: Results were validated through comparison against traditional benchmarks and standard cybersecurity frameworks.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: Adherence to data privacy regulations was considered, focusing on ethical implications of LLM use in cybersecurity.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.compliance_with_regulations: Considerations for GDPR and other regulatory frameworks.
